thread.title: Starbucks Was Never Cheap
thread.title_full: Starbucks Was Never Cheap

posts.title: Starbucks Was Never Cheap
posts.text:
Operated by smart, honest, forward-thinking management 
S 
Sells for an attractive price Click to enlarge Starbucks is doing a lot things right: opening new stores (2,100 net new stores globally in fiscal 2017), experimenting with new innovative store concepts (upscale Starbucks Reserve stores), expanding its breakfast and lunch menus, and more, to provide customers a unique experience. The business has favorable long-term prospects, and an experienced management team that will build up the Starbucks brand and take it to the next level. Here's what CEO Howard Schultz had to say about the 4% U.S. same-store sales in Q4 during the conference call : 
"Can I add one thing? Without putting anyone on the defensive and recognizing this is like the third rail, I would just ask you to consider that for a company our size and the track record that we have had domestically and now internationally, and as Kevin (President and COO) said in his remarks, the fact that our business went up on our scale during this quarter in every day-part. 
"And if you look at our history of trying to do everything we can to really add shareholder value in everything we do, to just try and just take a step back every now and then and recognize that comp store sales, although we all recognize its importance, is not the driving force of a company that did $20 billion in revenue and $4 billion in operating profit and is adding a store a day in China and is on its way to building one of the most recognized and admired brands in the world. And yet, we're so focused on something that, yes, it is important and it is strategic, but it is not everything. So just maybe every now and then recognize that we will have comps that will over-achieve and we'll have some comps that probably will disappoint. 
"But we are here for the long game. This is a 24th year of our public life. The company had a market cap of $250 million at that point. It's at almost $80 billion today. And it's just the beginning. So maybe every now and then just recognize we're all in this together and comps is not the end all of everything." There's much more to Starbucks than comp numbers, as Mr. Schultz argued, for example, Starbucks' consumer packaged goods (NYSE: CPG ) business and servicing China. These are two areas that still have much room for growth. Reshaping China's coffee and tea culture Starbucks is delivering strong revenues, profits, comp growth and ROI (>60%) in China. But China is in the early stages of development and there's still plenty of growth to be tapped. Starbucks recently launched Teavana beverages and teas in China (and Asia-Pacific regions) to accommodate the nation's traditional tea-drinking culture. Starbucks purchased Teavana in 2012 for $620 million and operates about 300 Teavana branded stores in Canada and the U.S. There are no Teavana branded stores in China, but I believe in the coming years, Starbucks will consider opening Teavana stores to further address China's $9.5 billion tea market that's estimated to grow at 4% per year to 2020. Additionally, the partnership with Chinese noodles and beverage company Tingyi will extend the reach of Starbucks ready-to-drink portfolio to Chinese consumers. Starbucks opened its first coffee shop in China in 1999. Today, there's 2,400 stores with plans in place to open 2,500 more stores by 2021. China's fast-growing middle class, rising disposable incomes, and the country's transition to a consumer-driven economy should benefit Starbucks, McDonald's, KFC, and other foodservice brands. Click to enlarge Source: Company reports Shopping for Starbucks drinks Starbucks' CPG business doesn't get quite as much attention, but it's a valuable differentiating factor when compared to competitors such as McDonald's, KFC and Restaurant Brands International (Burger King and Tim Hortons). McDonald's and Tim Hortons, for example, sell packaged ground coffee and K-Cups, but that's about it. Starbucks leads those two markets with brands such as Pike Place Roast, Starbucks Reserve, Seattle's Best Coffee, and Torrefazione Italia. Starbucks has started to extend its packaged product portfolio by entering the coffee, tea, and fruit ready-to-drink market under various brands (e.g. Evolution Fresh, Cold Brew, Tazo, Teavana). Starbucks is now competing against PepsiCo, Coca-Cola, and Dr Pepper and Snapple, all of which sell their own ready-to-drink coffee and teas. Source: Starbucks The CPG business registered revenues of $1.49 billion in fiscal 2016, up 12% from last year, and returning good volume and price growth (and greater share) in grocery stores. Starbucks has about 500 signature aisles in grocery stores and I expect this number to grow as Starbucks pushes its iced coffees and teas, fruit smoothies, and other ready-to-drink beverages onto every Wal-Mart, Whole Foods, Safeway, and Loblaws shelf over the long run. Starbucks is quickly becoming a larger CPG company with its own distribution and retail network. The announced PepsiCo, Tingyi, and Anheuser-Busch partnerships will broaden Starbucks CPG business and take it into new and existing markets. Click to enlarge Starbucks coffee aisle at Safeway. Source: Company reports, SupermarketNews Starbucks was never cheap I often hear that Starbucks' stock is expensive with a price-to-earnings multiple of ~30x (forward P/E at ~25x) compared to S&P 500 at 20x earnings. They say they will wait until the stock gets cheaper. But when was it ever cheap in the first place? Historically, Starbucks has never traded for less than 20x earnings since its IPO in 1992. If you're waiting to pick the bottom on Starbucks, then your timing the market, and that puts you at risk of possibly missing the stocks top-performing days. Timing the market can be costly, and instead, I recommend adopting a disciplined approach to long-term investing: Buy and hold. Starbucks has underperformed this year, but we have seen companies underperform in the past. If you look back, Starbucks has been one of the best performers in the S&P 500 for the last 20 years. An initial investment of $10,000 into Starbucks 10 years ago, would have grown to $31,401.87 today. This is a price-only return of 214.02% (excluding dividends). Investing in Starbucks 20 years ago, your $10,000 investment would have grown to $253,866.67 today. This is the power of compound interest, and long-term investing. I discussed market timing in a recent article called, " Donald Trump, Black Swans, and Fortune Tellers " So, what's Starbucks' stock worth? My valuation arrived at a target price of $65.00 (14% upside potential from the current market price) versus consensus of $64.50. I applied a target EV/EBITDA multiple of 17x to my 2017e EBITDA of $5.7 billion, which is at a premium to Starbucks' restaurant peer group average. I believe Starbucks deserves a premium valuation because of its market leadership, relative gross margin profile (60.1% in FY16), strong comparable store sales growth (4% to 6%), and compelling growth trajectory over the medium-to-long term in coffee and tea markets globally. My assumptions include a 7% 2017e EBITDA growth rate, share buybacks reducing 2017e shares O/S (f.d) by 1.5%, and keeping net debt constant. Figure 1: Comparables Figure 2: Starbucks valuation Figure 3: Sensitivity analysis This is my valuation and it may give you an idea on Starbucks' value and forward return trajectory. What it doesn't tell you is the path to $65. The stock could climb and run past my target price easily or the stock could decline before reaching my valuation. No one can accurately tell you where the market will go and the actual magnitude of future returns. What I do know is that in 5 years, 10 years, and 20 years from now, Starbucks will be generating more sales by selling more coffee and tea globally. Starbucks is a well-managed business, with stable competitive position, excellent brands, predictable cash flows and high returns on invested capital. If you understand what makes the business great, then it will be much easier for you to determine when the business is no longer great, and it's time for you to sell the stock. Starbucks' stock is trading at 30x earnings, is down 5% this year, and is underperforming the S&P 500 by 13.3%. Should you sell the stock? The answer is a resounding no. Buy and hold. thread.title_full: Starbucks Again Flexes Its Pricing Muscle

posts.title: Starbucks Again Flexes Its Pricing Muscle
posts.text:
Starbucks Again Flexes Its Pricing Muscle Nov.23.16 
Starbucks recently issued another price hike on select products. 
Starbucks is leveraging its powerful brand power to drive margin and cash flows higher. 
Are shares a buy at these prices? News spread shortly after the US election, that customers had noticed that prices for various beverages at their local Starbucks (NYSE: SBUX ) had gone up. Reported by The Street on Monday, and confirmed by Starbucks on Tuesday - Starbucks did issue a 10-30 cent raise on prices for certain cold drinks, and bakery goods. This marks the second time this year, that Starbucks has issued a price increase. Click to enlarge Starbucks is continually raising prices - once in 2014, again in 2015, and twice in 2016. The multiple price increases in 2016 were issued in order to protect healthy operating margins after major cost increases hit over the summer in the form of wage increases , and the rise of coffee prices. Coffee prices have risen steadily since winter. Click to enlarge source: CNBC The price increases helped Starbucks improve on profitability, as documented in its recent filing of Q4 earnings. Starbucks managed a 180 basis point improvement on operating margin over Q4 of last year (now up to 21.5%). For fiscal year 2016, Starbucks has expanded its margin 80 basis points to 19.6% Maintaining (and expanding) these robust margins while Starbucks continues to expand across the globe (primary focus being China) has continually boosted Starbucks' cash flows and earnings growth. Cash flows for 2016 have risen to $4.57B from $3.74B, and non-GAAP earnings per share are up 17% over fiscal year 2015 to $1.85 per share. Maintaining margins is a key component to driving growth forward. Starbucks is still rapidly expanding with 2,042 new stores opened company wide in 2016, and another 2,100 stores targeted to open in 2017. Starbucks has been able to do this while aggressively growing its dividend, and maintaining a very strong balance sheet with total debt of only $3.6B. Starbucks' debt is well covered by its cash flows, giving it flexibility to continue aggressive expansion. While there is fair concern about whether customers will get fed up with Starbucks' continual price increases, Starbucks puts tremendous focus on maintaining the Starbucks brand. Both its mobile app payment system, and Starbucks Rewards program are seeing continued growth. Customers enjoy the inviting atmosphere that Starbucks provides, as it has become a popular place for customers to "set up shop" and work/study while having coffee. These programs, combined with the atmosphere Starbucks stores provides for customers - should optimize customer retention, and help minimize those who leave the brand for cost effective alternatives like Dunkin' Brands Group (Dunkin' Donuts)(NYSE: DNKN ), or McDonald's Corp. (NYSE: MCD ). Click to enlarge This combination of premium product, atmosphere, and customer service is currently unmatched in the industry. Median households have finally started to rise again , and consumer spending is expected to continue rising as well. This should further help customers absorb price increases that will likely continue into the future. Click to enlarge The dividend was recently boosted by management to the tune of a 25% increase. This is consistent with previous hikes, as the dividend is growing at about 30% annually going back 10 years. With earnings expected to grow at a slightly lesser rate of 16-17% over the next five years, the dividend may slow down slightly from its torrid pace moving forward. The biggest problem with Starbucks shares at the moment is the price. Starbucks is currently trading at 27X next year's earnings. This valuation prices in very high expectations that could send shares tumbling at the first sign of imperfection. Starbucks is a fantastic company with many years of quality growth ahead of it. However, the past 5 years of growth is a tough act to follow. International expansion - specifically China must work like a charm. I would be a buyer at 23X earnings which would place the price in the high $40s. I understand that it will likely take a nice size market correction to get there, but a fantastic company can be a poor investment if you pay too much. If you liked this article, please find my profile icon at the top of this page, and hit the "Follow" button. I enjoy engaging with those who comment, and am always looking for feedback that allows me to improve on the content I provide. As always, thanks for reading. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. Starbucks takes mobile payments to 260 stores in Indonesia By Rian Boden • nfcworld.com • Published 23 November 2016, 12:35 • Last updated 23 November 2016, 12:35 
Customers at coffee chain Starbucks in Indonesia can now make mobile payments at 260 stores nationwide by scanning a barcode at the point of sale using the company’s mobile app and completing the payment using a registered Starbucks Card. 
“Customers can register multiple Starbucks Cards onto their account, all of which are linked to the Starbucks mobile app,” Starbucks says. “In addition to mobile payment, the Starbucks Indonesia mobile app puts the latest information on Starbucks products at customers’ fingertips with an easy-to-browse menu of beverage, food and merchandise as well as a convenient store locator.” 
Starbucks is also giving customers a complimentary drink with any beverage bought using a mobile device. Digital space 
“We are pleased to introduce the Starbucks Indonesia Mobile App to our customers, offering a fast and convenient way to pay for purchases, earn Stars and much more,” says Roger van Tongeren, vice president of marketing and operations at Starbucks Indonesia. 
“This is the latest Starbucks innovation which aims to provide an enhanced experience and meet customers’ needs in the digital space.”

thread.title: Ember Mug Sold At Starbucks Will Keep Drink At Your Preferred Temperature For Hours
thread.title_full: Ember Mug Sold At Starbucks Will Keep Drink At Your Preferred Temperature For Hours

posts.title: Ember Mug Sold At Starbucks Will Keep Drink At Your Preferred Temperature For Hours
posts.text:
11/23/16 AT 11:35 AM Close 
Ember Technologies recently released a fancy mug to keep your coffee or tea at your preferred temperature for hours, which you can buy at Starbucks . 
The leak-proof, portable mug keeps your drink at the temperature you want for up to two hours or all day if it’s connected to its charging coaster. 
The fancy mug has a sleek black look and has no buttons or with complicated instructions to keep your drink warm. The temperature is featured on the mug’s lit display and coffee lovers just need to rotate the dial on the bottom of the mug to the temperature they want. Ember say its design allows consumer feel like they’re drinking from a ceramic mug with its “perfect lip interface and a 360° drinking experience.” 
The mug can also be controlled by Ember’s smartphone or smartwatch app. With the app, you can adjust the temperature remotely, choose and save temperature presets for different drinks and allows you to name your mug. 
The Ember mug is the first of its kind and it costs $149.95. 
“The release of the Ember mug is seven years in the making. I started Ember to solve a simple yet universal challenge faced by coffee and tea drinkers everywhere - how can I keep my hot beverage at the ideal temperature for as long as I want,” said Ember Technologies Founder and CEO Clay Alexander in a press release . 
Ember's new mug that keeps drinks at preferred temperature now sold a Starbucks. Photo: Ember Technologies Related Stories Millennials, Climate Change May Be Killing The World's Coffee Supply 
Ember notes on its website the average serving temperature for coffee is 160 degrees fahrenheit, yet the average preferred drinking temperature is around 135 degrees fahrenheit. 
“We put so much effort into making that perfect cup of coffee, so why do we go and pour it into a paper cup or mug only to end up with a coffee that’s scalding hot or lukewarm?” Alexander, who has a background in thermoscience, said in a promo . 
The Ember has a stainless steel inner vessel, patented microprocessor controlled heating system and the mug’s lid has a push to open mechanism. The Ember mug comes with a charging coaster and high capacity battery, and was designed by Ammunition Group, the same people that designed the Beats by Dre headphones. 
The mugs are sold at Starbucks stores (check map to see which ones) and the Ember and Starbucks websites.

thread.title: Starbucks: A Latte Upside Left

posts.title: Starbucks: A Latte Upside Left
posts.text:
Summary 
Starbucks is set for its first close above its 200-day moving average in over 7 months. 
Despite a massive rally in coffee prices this year, the stock has managed to hold its weekly support at $52.00. 
The company continues to report growing earnings each year, as well as earnings growth over their previous year's quarters. In a year when coffee prices (NYSEARCA: JO ) have seen a 20% YTD return, Starbucks (NASDAQ: SBUX ) is still managing to stand its ground. While the stock has certainly not had a year for shareholders to write home about, the slightly negative year to date return is not cause for worry. The stock has been one of the best performers for the past 7 years, posting a 1000% plus return since mid 2009. The stock has been consolidating between a range of $51 and $63 since late 2015, and this is perfectly normal after the run it has had. Click to enlarge Click to enlarge (Source: TC2000.com) Starbucks used to be everyone's most loved company on the long side, but it seems that sentiment came to a screeching halt this year. There has been a wealth of writers recommending shorts on the stock, and even longs have begun to get a little nervous. Just this week CNBC's Dan Nathan recommended a bearish options trade on the stock, with a break-even on the trade of $54.00. With the majority turning bearish despite the stock remaining above support, I am looking the other way. I went long Starbucks stock yesterday at $56.50 as it finally regained its 200-day moving average. Click to enlarge (Source: TC2000.com) My strategy for trading stocks is a trend-following approach as I'm a huge proponent of Richard Dennis. Richard Dennis was a commodities speculator known as the "Prince of the Pit" at the Chicago Board of Trade. He had a remarkable career , becoming a millionaire before the age of 26. Richard Dennis later taught complete strangers to trade his Turtle Trading Strategy . Some of the original "Turtles" still trade today and have seen massive success from his teachings. Jerry Parker (one of Dennis's disciples) founded Chesapeake Capital in 1988, and currently manages over $1.5 billion. Dennis's success came from his style of hitting massive home run trades on his winners, despite several strikeouts. His strategy was to let his winners run as long as they remained in an uptrend, and cut his losers as soon as they invalidated their uptrend. I have tweaked Dennis's Turtle Trading system in a few ways to better adapt to current markets, and my risk profile. Despite this being a purely technical system, this does not mean I ignore fundamentals. I am also a large believer in William O'Neil's CANSLIM method, and use the "CAN" to help select fundamentally strong stocks. The "CAN" in his CANSLIM method stands for the following: C - Current Earnings : William pointed out the importance of choosing stocks whose earnings per share (EPS) in their most recent quarter had grown from the previous year. A - Annual Earnings : William also believed annual earnings growth to be very important. Companies being selected for investments according to William should have good annual earnings growth over the past 5 years. As William stated "Who wants to own part of an establishment showing no growth?" Due to this, William recommended buying stocks with annual earnings growth of at least 25%. N - New : The N in Williams CANSLIM stock selection approach stood for new, which meant the company recently underwent a change of some type. Whether it be a new product, entering a new market, or a new high in price. In my application of this method, I place the most emphasis on a new high in price as this confirms my primary trading strategy. By combining these two systems, I am able to find fundamentally strong stocks, while timing my entries to generate maximum returns. While most buy and hold investors simply buy good companies and hold for the long term, I wait for confirmation to buy. My confirmation signal is new 3-month highs for the stock, while it trades above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Putting Starbucks Through The "CAN" Screener Click to enlarge (Source: YCharts.com) C - Current Earnings : As we can see from the above table, Starbucks is a perfect fit for O'Neil's "C" requirements. The company has seen growth over all of its previous quarters, and by a wide margin in most cases. Starbucks saw diluted EPS increase 25% in Q3 over the prior year, as well as 24% diluted EPS growth in their Q2 report. I believe this to be extremely impressive given the fact the company is facing headwinds from strength in the price of coffee. Click to enlarge A - Annual Earnings : Zooming out to annual earnings, we can see that growth is not quite up to O'Neil's preferred 25% year over year. Having said that, the company continues to grow diluted EPS year over year, despite also increasing its yield. Starbucks reported $1.63 in diluted EPS last year, and is currently on track to beat that number. The company has reported $1.44 in earnings thus far in the first nine months, and should see more than $0.50 of diluted EPS in Q4. This would place their full year earnings at $1.94, giving them a roughly 20% growth rate in annual earnings over last year. Click to enlarge (Source: TC2000.com) N - New : In terms of the new category, Starbucks has several new positive developments technically. The stock is currently on track for its first close above its 40-week moving average in six months, while the stock makes new 3-month highs. My buy signal for stocks comes when they make new 3-month highs, and my line in the sand for bull and bear markets is the 40-week moving average. These two developments are very bullish for investors in Starbucks, and I expect that the stock will begin to play catch-up with the market going forward. Technical Outlook & Summary Taking a look at the daily chart of Starbucks, we can see that the stock has been locked in a down-sloping channel. This down-sloping channel has obvious lower lows and lower highs, but Starbucks looking to be challenging the top of this channel currently. What's different about this current down-sloping channel test is that the stock is already well above its 200-day moving average (yellow line). This is a very good sign for the channel test as a close above the 200-day moving average puts the momentum back into most stocks. Click to enlarge (Source: TC2000.com) As we can see in the past 2 times the stock got near the top of the channel, Starbucks came up short at its 200-day moving average. Despite poking its head slightly above this level in intra-day trading, it was a brick wall of resistance when it came to closing above it. The fact that Starbucks closed above the 200-day moving average with a vengeance yesterday, tells me that this is likely the beginning of a new uptrend. So what if I am wrong on Starbucks? If I am wrong on this long position from $56.50, I always have a stop on my trade. This is done to protect myself, as the goal of trend following is to cut your losers quickly. My method of placing a stop is to find a level where I believe my trade thesis to be invalidated. Before I enter any long position on a stock, I want to know what my maximum pain is if the trade goes sour. Without knowing my maximum pain, there is no possible way to know how much of a stock I am going to buy. Given my risk profile, I only allow myself 1.0% 1.2% portfolio risk on any one trade. The goal of trend following is to stay in the game as long as possible, in order to give enough time to exploit the edge provided by trend following. My winners tend to be 3 times the size of my losers, which allows me to have a 60% win/loss ratio and still be very profitable. My 1.0 - 1.2 rule is in place to protect myself from losing streaks, and to ensure one bad losing streak does not wipe me out. If my risk on each trade was 10% of my account, one bad distribution of winners to losers could bankrupt my portfolio. My stop on my Starbucks trade is at $50.83 which gives me a risk of $5.67 from my entry at $56.50. This means that I am allowed to use a position size of 10-11% of my account to enter Starbucks to stay within my 1.0 - 1.2 rule. I have shown an example of how I calculate this above to help readers understand my position sizing example better. Given the fact that I bought 100 shares of Starbucks at $56.50, my total risk on this trade is 1.13% of my portfolio. The reason I have used a stop below the $50.83 level is for 2 reasons: Click to enlarge (Source: TC2000.com) 1) A close below $50.83 would completely invalidate this 3-month high breakout, and see the stock well below its 200-day moving average. 2) A close below $50.83 would also constitute new 52-week lows for the stock, and I have no interest in being long from 52-week lows. I believe Starbucks to be an excellent long candidate for those looking for a growth stock for their accounts. While growth has tapered off in the past 2 years, the company is still maintaining modest growth while continuing to raise its dividend. The technical backdrop on the stock has switched to bullish this week, and I believe there is a good chance a new uptrend is beginning. If coffee prices continue to decline from their elevated sentiment readings of 90% bulls during October, this would also help Starbucks bottom line. Despite many looking to the short side on Starbucks, I am taking a stab at the stock from the long side. If I am wrong my downside is protected, and if I'm right I have a low risk entry in a solid company with momentum behind it. (Source: TC2000.com) For full transparency I have shown all of my equity positions above that I have highlighted in the past 12 months in my articles. As you can see while I have only slightly more winners than losers, my winners tend to be much larger than my losers. This is the reason that trend following remains my favorite strategy for my actively managed accounts. Disclosure: I am/we are long SBUX. thread.title: Starbucks fans, you won’t be pleased about this devastating news
thread.title_full: Starbucks fans, you won’t be pleased about this devastating news

posts.author: Stephanie Hallett
posts.title: Starbucks fans, you won’t be pleased about this devastating news
posts.text:
Starbucks fans, you won’t be pleased about this devastating news The last thing you want to hear during the most expensive time of year is that your favorite coffee drink is going up in price, but that’s the sad news we have to deliver today from Starbucks . The company quietly raised prices on many of its cold beverages and baked goods on November 10th by between $0.10 and $0.30, jacking up the average customer’s bill by about 0.5%.
The company last raised prices in July , increasing the cost of select sizes of brewed coffee by $0.10 to $0.20, and the price of espresso and tea latte drinks by between $0.10 and $0.30.
Toasty on the inside, toasty on the outside. #ChestnutPralineLatte 
A photo posted by Starbucks Coffee ☕ (@starbucks) on Nov 3, 2016 at 9:23am PDT 
This is the fourth time in three years that Starbucks has raised its prices, likely because of lower-than-expected sales growth . A rep for Starbucks explained the rationale for raising prices to Consumerist, saying, “We continually evaluate pricing on a product-by-product and market-by-market basis in our stores in order to balance our business needs while continuing to provide value to our loyal customers and to attract new customers.”
Celebrating #EarlyThanksgiving with a #TurkeyStuffingPanini... and an ever-growing list of things to be thankful for. 
A photo posted by Starbucks Coffee ☕ (@starbucks) on Nov 21, 2016 at 10:22am PST 
While price hikes suck for consumers, the upside is that Starbucks employees recently got a raise of at least 5% nationwide; with more than 150,000 employees working in 7,670 stores, that raise will surely help a lot of individuals and families — especially during the holiday season.
So let’s try to look on that bright side, shall we?
The post Starbucks fans, you won’t be pleased about this devastating news appeared first on HelloGiggles .

thread.title: Starbucks Quietly Raised Prices for Second Time in Months - Cold Drinks, Baked Goods Cost More
thread.title_full: Starbucks Quietly Raised Prices for Second Time in Months - Cold Drinks, Baked Goods Cost More

posts.author: Megan Friedman
posts.title: Starbucks Quietly Raised Prices for Second Time in Months - Cold Drinks, Baked Goods Cost More
posts.text:
Your Starbucks habit just got even more expensive. Consumerist reports that Starbucks has upped the price of some cold drinks and baked goods by anywhere from 10 to 30 cents. The price hike, which took effect on November 10, will cause a customer's total to go up by 0.5% on average. About 90% of items on the Starbucks menu will stay the same price.
The company didn't say why it was raising prices. According to The Street , sales growth has slowed for Starbucks in the United States, so raising prices could help the company's bottom line. Just this past July, Starbucks raised its prices on brewed coffee, espresso, and tea lattes by as much as 30 cents. That's unusual for Starbucks, which usually ups prices between 5 and 20 cents each year.
 "We continually evaluate pricing on a product-by-product and market-by-market basis in our stores in order to balance our business needs while continuing to provide value to our loyal customers and to attract new customers," a representative for Starbucks told Consumerist.
Customers weren't too thrilled with the price hike, and posted their sticker shock on Twitter.
Fuck you Starbucks for raising the price of your cold drinks. I'm still going to buy them but fuck you
— Leanna (@hankheel) November 22, 2016 #starbucks must you raise the price of cold drinks? I already feel I am getting less for my money getting cold given it's mostly water...
— Lucy Sky (@PaperbackLucy) November 22, 2016 Just stop drinking @Starbucks so they'll lower the prices... You shouldn't be paying the price of a meal for a stupid latte. 👎
— Lauren Mayhew (@LaurenMayhew_) November 22, 2016 @Starbucks did a price hike back in July and now they're doing another price hike? #greedy
— jazuela (@jazuela34) November 21, 2016 @Starbucks as much as I love my daily grande iced coffee, yet another price increase this year means a decrease in my visits. Too damn high!
— Layla S. (@TVTweets101) November 21, 2016
From: Delish

thread.title: This Pumpkin Spice Latte Comes With a Miniature Pumpkin Pie on Top
thread.title_full: This Pumpkin Spice Latte Comes With a Miniature Pumpkin Pie on Top

posts.author: Chris Fuhrmeister
posts.title: This Pumpkin Spice Latte Comes With a Miniature Pumpkin Pie on Top
posts.text: This Pumpkin Spice Latte Comes With a Miniature Pumpkin Pie on Top Your move, Starbucks share The pumpkin spice latte market is getting crowded, forcing would-be PSL purveyors to innovate in order to stand out from the crowd. Since the beverage’s flavor profile is inspired by pumpkin pie, and not actual pumpkin, one Los Angeles coffeeshop has come up with the perfect garnish. Behold: The miniature pumpkin pie-topped PSL at Go Get Em Tiger . A photo posted by Go Get Em Tiger (@ggetla) on Nov 23, 2016 at 8:15am PST The beverage, available this Thursday from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., has become a Thanksgiving tradition for the shop in recent years. Break the pie into the beverage, consume, and let the autumn-inspired basicness wash over you. The next-level PSL isn’t the only eye-popping Turkey Day special from Go Get Em Tiger. Eater LA has a look at the full menu , which includes a gingerbread latte (actually a milkshake garnished with a gingerbread cookie), peppermint mocha (peppermint ganache mixed with espresso, topped with mint-infused whipped cream and a candied mint leaf, served in an edible chocolate cup), and toffee nut latte (an homage to Cup O’ Noodles: a cup of toffee, instant coffee, steamed almond macadamia milk). Starbucks might have a PSL mascot with its own Twitter account , but Go Get Em Tiger is bringing the heat. It might be time for the Seattle-based behemoth to step up its game.

thread.title: Starbucks Raises Prices For Second Time In Four Months – Consumerist
thread.title_full: Starbucks Raises Prices For Second Time In Four Months – Consumerist

posts.author: Ashlee Kieler
posts.title: Starbucks Raises Prices For Second Time In Four Months – Consumerist
posts.text:
Image courtesy of Louis Abate 
November 22, 2016 12:40 pm EST By Ashlee Kieler @akieler here we go again starbucks coffee cool coffee at a price Price Increase expensive drinks baked goods 
Four months after Starbucks surprised customers by accidentally pushing out its annual price increase two weeks early , the company had another shocker for guests: a second price increase for some drinks and food items. 
Starbucks increased the price for certain cold drinks and bakery items by $0.10 to $0.30 earlier this month, the company confirmed to Consumerist. 
A rep for the coffee giant says the increases don’t affect about 90% of the company’s beverages, such as hot tea, brewed coffee, espresso and prepared items. Still, the company expects affected customers’ tabs to increase by 0.5% on average. 
“We continually evaluate pricing on a product-by-product and market-by-market basis in our stores in order to balance our business needs while continuing to provide value to our loyal customers and to attract new customers,” the rep said. 
While the second price increase only affects cold beverages, which might not have that much appeal during these chilly months, some Starbucks customers expressed their displeasure on Twitter at paying more at the counter. So apperntly in the past 2 months I've been away at college, the price of frappuccinos at @Starbucks went up by 30¢!

posts.title: Starbucks raising prices on baked goods, some drinks
posts.text:
(CNN) - It's going to cost more for your cold drink and muffin at Starbucks.
The coffee chain says prices for certain cold drinks and baked goods went up 10 to 30 cents earlier this month.
Starbucks did not explain the price index.
About 90 percent of the Starbucks beverage menu, including hot coffee and tea, did not see prices change.
Back in July, Starbucks raised the price of some coffee drinks by as much as 20 cents, while espresso and latte beverages saw prices rise from 10 to 30 cents.

thread.title: 'Pokemon Go' Generation 2 release date rumors: Launch date leaked via alleged Starbucks internal memo
thread.title_full: 'Pokemon Go' Generation 2 release date rumors: Launch date leaked via alleged Starbucks internal memo

posts.title: 'Pokemon Go' Generation 2 release date rumors: Launch date leaked via alleged Starbucks internal memo
posts.text:
(REUTERS/Ilya Naymushin) Pokemon Go Hub has created a user-friendly chance calculator to help players save limited resources when capturing a Pokemon 
There's exactly no way to determine whether it's really a clever publicity stunt done by Niantic, Inc. or an honest mistake, but people may now already have a clear idea on when the purported version 2 of the hit augmented reality mobile game, "Pokemon Go" will come out. 
Rumors have been plaguing the fandom that the developers are looking to add a hundred more Pokemon into the game. As early as October, it's been heard that this new slate of Pokemon will come from Generation 2 which avid followers of the franchise may consider the most popular among the "Pokemon" generations. 
In a report , it says that there's already been some mention of that particular generation in "Pokemon Go's" code, but it was only now that the a specific date has been mentioned. 
In what way was the public able to get hold of the information? Advertisement 
According to iDigital Times , a Redditor who claims to be working for Starbucks did what is considered as a breach of confidentiality by sharing what looks like an internal memo with the details pertaining to a certain "Version 2" update of "Pokemon Go." There's also the talk of Groupon promotions, Facebook, and Verizon promotions but the highlight pertains to that of the hit mobile game. 
As indicated in the image of the memo shared over the publication, it says that the update will be rolled out this Dec. 7 which the coffee chain store will "take a great part" of. "Lures will be dropped..." the memo added. 
The person in question did clarify in his post that he really can't be sure if the memorandum really refers to the "Pokemon" Generation 2 and or Starbucks and Niantic are collaborating on this particular event. However, the "Pokemon Frapuccino" is quite indicative of the case. 
Watch out for more updates.
